title: Modified Minnesota Detoxification Scale (mMINDS)
description: Scores symptoms for patients with alcohol withdrawal syndrome, particularly useful in critically ill patients and ICU settings

parameters.name: pulse
parameters.description: Pulse rate in beats per minute

parameters.name: agitation
parameters.description: Level of agitation using Richmond Agitation-Sedation Scale principles

parameters.name: orientation
parameters.description: Level of orientation to person, place, and time

parameters.name: delusions
parameters.description: Presence of delusions or inability to assess due to sedation

parameters.name: seizures
parameters.description: Active seizure activity at time of assessment

result.name: mminds_score
result.description: Modified Minnesota Detoxification Scale score for alcohol withdrawal severity

ranges.interpretation: Minimal alcohol withdrawal symptoms. Clinical observation may be sufficient. Consider symptom-triggered therapy.
Mild alcohol withdrawal syndrome. Consider benzodiazepine therapy. Monitor closely for progression.
Moderate alcohol withdrawal syndrome. Benzodiazepine therapy indicated. Consider ICU monitoring if score increasing.
Severe alcohol withdrawal syndrome with high risk for delirium tremens. Aggressive benzodiazepine therapy required. ICU monitoring strongly recommended.

references: Hack JB, Hoffmann RS, Nelson LS. Resistant alcohol withdrawal: does an unexpectedly large sedative requirement identify these patients early? J Med Toxicol. 2006 Jun;2(2):55-60. doi: 10.1007/BF03161175.
Awissi DK, Lebrun G, Fagnan M, Skrobik Y. Alcohol, nicotine, and iatrogenic withdrawals in the ICU. Crit Care Med. 2013 Sep;41(9 Suppl 1):S57-68. doi: 10.1097/CCM.0b013e3182a168d5.

DeCarolis DD, Rice KL, Ho L, Willenbring ML, Cassaro S. Symptom-driven lorazepam protocol for treatment of severe alcohol withdrawal delirium in the intensive care unit. Pharmacotherapy. 2007 Apr;27(4):510-8. doi: 10.1592/phco.27.4.510.

Foy A, March S, Drinkwater V. Use of an objective clinical scale in the assessment and management of alcohol withdrawal in a large general hospital. Alcohol Clin Exp Res. 1988 Jun;12(3):360-4. doi: 10.1111/j.1530-0277.1988.tb00208.x.
formula: Sum of points from all 9 parameters: Pulse (0-2), DBP (0-2), Tremor (0-6), Sweat (0-6), Hallucinations (0-3), Agitation (0-9), Orientation (0-6), Delusions (0-6), Seizures (0-6). Range: 0-46 points.
notes: Specifically designed for use in critically ill patients and ICU settings
Preferred over CIWA-Ar in patients who cannot provide subjective responses
If unable to assess a parameter due to over-sedation or mechanical ventilation, score = 0
Validated primarily in medical and surgical intensive care units
Associated with shorter ICU stays and reduced benzodiazepine use compared to CIWA-Ar
Helps guide symptom-triggered benzodiazepine therapy protocols
More objective assessment compared to subjective scales like CIWA-Ar
Scores â‰¥21 indicate moderate to severe withdrawal requiring aggressive treatment
Consider ICU monitoring for progressive increases in score or scores >20
Useful for monitoring treatment response and titrating benzodiazepine therapy
